comments.commentBody: Gray, Freddie Gray. I respect your response, but please remember this man's name.

According to the source you linked to, "By 2011, law enforcement shootings caused 2.74 deaths for every million blacks, and 1.28 deaths for every million whites."

That would, in fact, mean that police officers kill black Americans at twice the rate of white Americans, which is exactly the opposite of what your headline says. You have at least a 2x chance of being kill by a cop if you are black than if you are white.
This is a start but there is one thing Hillary can do that will not jeopardize her standing with unions and cops _ support the legalization of marijuana and end the Drug War. It drives much of this.

Perfect weeknight meal came together quickly.  Followed the great suggestion to cook the asparagus in the pasta water and didn't bother with shocking in cold water.  I also mixed some lemon zest with the dill for a 'gremolata' style garnish.  Delicious!

In the end, people are looking for respect, stability and safety.   Mr. Savage and other like-minded individuals are reaching those ends through constructive means, earning credibility and establishing a livable community.  Those on the other end, the active gangs and the looters we saw in Baltimore, are looking to intimidate and take away others' lifelines.  The actual self-empowerment will win a community from the throes of destruction, and if that message needs to come from one who saw the err of his ways, more power to him!

If this is an example of Hillary leading from behind, what do you say about all of the other Presidential candidates who've said little or nothing on the matter? Call it leading from behind, but she's still out in front of every other candidate on this issue. I guess all the other candidates are leading from way way behind. Way way behind Hillary.

"Obama was elected because he was WHITE along with BLACK."

I have to disagree. Obama was elected President because he was simply the best candidate. He's smart, likeable, and has been on the right side of most issues (in a manner of speaking.) He instilled confidence in enough people to win a majority of the votes. If everything was the same except that his mother was black, I don't think the outcomes would have been different. Perhaps Republicans/conservatives would have hated him that much more, but it's hard to imagine them hating him any more than they already do.
You have no basis to  assume that the letter writer is funding his or her remodel with a Wall Street Banker Bonus.
Forget about your parents... If you're funding your remodel with a Wall Street banker bonus funded by a taxpayer bailout you ought (ethically) to send me a check for $10,000.

'...Their monthly fixed-retirement income of over $6,000 should be fine to sustain them...'

That is $72,000 a year, more than the majority of people make working full time.

Do not lend or give your parents any money, as there will be no end to it. They are like addicts who will drain your dry and never change, until they hit rock bottom.

If they have to sell their home and move into a rental, so be it. Tens of millions of American living on much less income do just that, even though they do not squander all their money.

My family comes from a place in the old country, they still use a horse to bring the hay down from the upper pastures, and didn't get electricity from the grid until the mid 1990's.  Probably the most natural place I have been.  One note don't wander in the fields on the back side of the hill,  the natural uranium levels are so high that if you spend too long there you'll trip radiation detectors at the airport.

We know the statistics and limited benefits of further prison-building and more punitive practices of incarceration--see http://wp.me/p36T6t-1Th, for starts. The one and a half million missing husbands, mothers, brothers, sisters, uncles, aunts, and family members have hurt our country more than we can say, or fully realize. They do tear at our soul, and thank you Hillary.

No one lives in NYC to see the stars.

That said, I am lucky enough to have a view of the Empire State Building from my windows and the lights shows are tacky and ugly. It is understandable that the building went LED and when the lights are the traditional white or muted colors for holidays, they look almost as they always did, but the bright loud Day Glo light shows are an abomination.

This is one of the most beautiful Art Deco buildings in the world. Not need to dress it up like a Las Vegas chorus girl.

This is a no-brainer. The level of lighting in the city is ridiculous. We're not going to be able to see the stars, but we could save a lot of energy with no downside.

And we don't need every landmark building lit up like a carnival 365 days a year either. It looks cheesy and I liked the empire state building before they started doing the colored light thing.

I love the skyline. It's beautiful! But we have to grow up and do the right thing.
And while we're at it, let's stop over air conditioning these buildings. People have to put on extra clothes to stay warm at work. It's so unnecessary and uncomfortable.

Some parts of your argument are compelling, but you lost me when you mentioned the (apparently famous) name of your former fiancee.  Or was it when you described signing the form requiring both parties' consent to bring the embryos to term?
It gets easier.  And more fun.  Like anything else.  I bet it was fabulous.

One wonders that the campaign corruption connection to Congress and other elected offices isn't as blatantly obvious to Roberts.

... but then, he's never held elected office; he's only been appointed, and confirmed, by those who do.

I'd add that another reason not to move it to the 1930s can be seen very clearly in the photographs — the women's dresses. It is set in a time and place of great sexual repression. Respectable women do not show their legs or even their bare arms in public. The theme of sexual repression in this town, along with bourgeois disapproval of any nonconformity, is very important in the piece. I look at the photos of the women in this production and I see the costumes, and I think those costumes subvert what the show is about.

That doesn't mean that a production can never change a time period. But the new time period has to make sense.

Rosemary, you're in luck:
http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/theater/video/chi-showcase-l...

Kids who are years too young to be trusted to buy a beer are certainly too young to grasp the reality of far-off possibilities such as personal combat months or years in the future.
We don't even recommend anymore that our 18-year-olds go straight to college after high school, because - though they're free to drop out of college anytime - so many of them need to experience a bit of real life before making that big an academic commitment, or it may easily become a personal failure or even a debt disaster.

Basic training does the opposite of "a bit of real life." It intentionally exhausts and suppresses individuality and reflection, instead instilling instant obedience and unquestioning performance.
To hold such a kid responsible for "understanding" possible combat at the time of enlistment is simply delusional. To imagine that they could wake up to the human reality of it after basic training is ridiculous. And even if they could, to expect that they might find a way to do anything about it while under total military control in a foreign setting is practically impossible.

Pilots may vary. And, why wouldn't they?
The only military pilot I knew well was a B-52 pilot who flew to work at the day's coordinates over Vietnam daily from a comfortable "home" at a Philippine air base. From high altitude, he never got the view of carpet-bombing's effects that this Pilot does of her drone strike successes. But after months of enough such days, the unseen and unknown got to him. He managed to "fake a psycho" and get discharged, even though it cost him his lifetime dream of a presitigious and lucrative life as an airline pilot. His only regret was having been unable for so long to realize the death and destruction he had caused.
Even the heroes of our "greatest generation" have often needed decades to face the deep-rooted psychological and moral consequences of the noble war they waged in the 1940s. The heroism and commitment are real, but so is the humanity inherent in all different individuals.
Seen it three times so far and going back with friends to see it a fourth. It's fun, and happy, and bright, and perfect for a Spring evening. Let the critics have their say, just go and enjoy.

Agreed.When I saw the show during previews I could say that the first act was relatively solid. However the second half needs a lot of work and there were a lot of half-jokes that weren't developed or landing. At times I feel like the writers just spun the "What makes a good musical" spinning wheel to develop the jokes, and not in a "The Producers" good kind of way. The joke sophistication is somewhere between campy and NYC Jew, constantly winking at the audience to the point of saying "I get it, I'm in NYC."  The show isn't timeless, and the themes are short-sighted, unrelatable, and incomprehensible at times if the show were to ever leave the Tri-state area. The second act is a shallow wreck book-wise, summed up with characters leaving stage in order to develop conflict later in the story, but had no reason to exit stage left pursued by bear in the first place. It is clear that no one really on the writing staff did any research to Shakespeare's time-line since the show opens at some time around 1594-1595 just around the closing of Romeo and Juliet and the written Sonnets, and ends with the performance of Hamlet in 1600 and the settling of what I hope is Jamestown in 1604. Yet, Bottom's wife, who is pregnant some time in 1595 gives birth in 1604, tells me that even the baby didn't want to be part of the production. If you're going to see a musical this season, just keep walking by this show's box office.

It was also done at the American Shakespeare Center in 2012.

http://www.americanshakespearecenter.com/v.php?pg=1133
Is this being staged in Delhi? It feels almost like a trial that has undergone a change of venue. Essential work, but to make change, maybe most essential to be seen where the stories originated...

I agree that the play itself is brilliant and that we are given two excellent performances by Mulligan and Nighy. Had we been given an actor actually appearing closer to fifty, we would have had a third character on stage: sexual tension, which would have taken this from fantastic to Explosive. Both performers radiated energy and belief, but with only a fondness between them, not fierceness.
Six years of hiding a relationship while working side by side with the wife would have created something beyond fond... And yes, Tom wants forgiveness and love, while Kyra, having finally woken up to what she was a part of for so long, can't remotely forgive herself and scorns Tom for thinking it possible. Her punishment for having been selfish and blind is to now be selfless and out there, seeing "the people" every day.
